WRITING.TEXT: I would advice downloading 'Grammarly' on your phone. It's free and automatically fixes most mistakes, so you don't have to worry about wasting your time with grammar and you won't have to worry about people not understanding your messages.
That's a really smart idea.
And I would've gotten away with it too.
Will the mouths of reason prevail? Didnt think so.
I tried to tell one of my friends that communism is bad. Never will I ever see someone get that angry so fast again.
Most of the money goes to supporting the massive bureaucracy anyways.
And if you don't hand the money over you go to jail.

It's always hard to see the perspective of the opposition, but they may have something of importance to say so don't hear, listen. Take socialism versus capitalism. If our society becomes too unequal the people at the bottom will riot and overthrow the government and start socialism; however, for every one unit of wealth you need three units of inequity, and if people, who work harder aren't rewarded with money or something else, they won't work harder (to strawman the point). The radical leftists have found a problem in our system, "what about poor people?" We can't just turn our backs on them. That's unethical; however, at the same time, we can't steal from the rich. So how do we fix the situation? Nobody knows. The people at the bottom made poor decisions and are paying for them, and the people at the top have made good decisions and have been rewarded. It's a just system. We can't steal to fix the issue! Doing a bad thing for a good cause is still bad. Anyone with any other opinions?
Nothing.

We need restricted capitalism. We can't have monopolies, but a free market creates wealth for everyone. One unit of wealth for every three of inequity, but we should reward those, who work hard to give us new products that we desire or else they won't give us those products. The free market may need to be reform, but let's try to improve a system working at 80% efficiency than one that works even less.

While this is a valid point, I disagree with the notion that we need a european-style social democracy. You will get benefits if you live in social democracies, but you must pay for them through taxes. Then if you decide you don't want health care you still have to pay the taxes. It's not fair that you have to pay for someone else's bills; however, your point about rich people having to much power over certain politicians is correct, but corruption is in every country.

True. Just out of curiosity would you be fine with nuclear power? Most of the clean energy folks have a grudge on nuclear power for some reason even though it's very clean because all the waste is put far underground where it can't do any harm. And if not why?
That happens too often. I've always been interested in the nuclear power area and have read my fair share of books on it.

Don't get me wrong, I'm not arguing for socialism; however, the liberals have a point. They have found a flaw in the best social system the world has ever created, but that doesn't mean that you need to dismantle it. We can work to fix it. If it is possible to do so without infringing on the rights of others, but our society needs a right and left. A bird cannot fly without two wings, but radicals it can do without.

Well, studies have found that the brain structure of conservatives and liberals do differ significantly. They may find a compromise that's better than just one side, but do you believe that the socialists have a point? That they have found a flaw? The liberals? The leftists, when it comes to this issue?

Regulations like the anti-trust act stabilize capitalism. Not a social democracy and not everyone needs health care or wants health care: however, most people do. I take issue with the opinion that we deserve anything. We don't. If you want something, you need to work to get it. It's not fair to the rich, who have worked hard to get their money when you take it away from them; however, money does tend to stay in family lines, but the same argument applies to that too. You don't get to take someone else's stuff because you think you deserve it. That's called greed. But the problem still remains that there are poor people, who got screwed over by the system. I just don't believe that they deserve what is not there's. There needs to be any other solution besides theft. Another problem is that the people at the bottom tend to be there for a reason. Most of the time they didn't get screwed. They screwed themselves. They got there by cheating, stealing, and lying. They got what they deserved. We need a system that will still be just, but allow the people, who are at the bottom and are undeserving. Climb the latter again. Any disagreements?
Lol
The main problem is that America has an average IQ of 96 not 100.
This is the reason at indoctrination centers (schools) they separate the classes in regular, honors, and ap. It's for the smart people's sake.
Immigrants aren't bad in themselves. It can be a very good thing; however, illegal immigrants are another thing.

It's not the immigrants. It was leaded gasoline. The correlation between IQ and leaded gasoline was quite high, I believe it has a moderate to strong correlation. They've stopped putting it is gasoline now.

Well, your graph the about of lead in the air via car emissions and IQ over time and solve for r then raise it to the second power and that's how much lead in the air explains the change in IQ. Let me check what r is if I can find it.
Couldn't find anything after a quick look, but there are more recent studies. Some in the 2000s.
I don't understand. Can you please reword your response.

They didn't take blood from one kid and said good enough. You need a large enough sample to draw conclusions about the population, which is normally above 40 and the odds that 40 children have an average IQ of above 115 is... Z=6.3246 or p= about zero.

Confounding usually occurs when you would think the data wouldn't be correlated. Here you would think the data would be in some way correlated. Lead is poisonous to people, but good for cars lets put it in gasoline. When put in gas it will also be emitted into the air. Then people inhale the air with lead. It builds up in them and eventually gets to the brain. Where it does what it normally does and makes you stupid. You would suppose that as the lead in the air increased IQ would decrease. But when the lead decreased after they stopped putting it in cars. The people stayed dumb, and no matter what you do IQ cannot be increased. Correlation doesn't mean causation. But the. Correlation coefficient means causation, but still could be off if the data were skewed in a certain direction by an unsavory experimentor. But more than just correlation has been calculated. And many tests have been done.

The correlation coefficient is how much out of 100 the two variables selected cause each other. And it is a major difference at the ends. So of the mean is 96 it will make people with genius level IQ significantly rarer. I just ran a 2 sample z test comparing 100 to 96 and the z is 3266 this means my data is significant at the 1E-3266 level. This is about as significant as it gets. I'm taking a college statistics course btw.

Lol, my prof told us that. I'm saying the evidence is strong for my case, who now maybe I'm wrong. Maybe the data is confounding. I don't know. However, a small difference in the mean can have large changes at the ends of the distribution. I'm just saying that our country mean IQ is lower than the true mu 100.

WRITING.TITLE: What was the best thing that made your year?
What is your opinion on the government mandating vaccinations?
WRITING.TEXT: I personally say yes to the government mandating vaccinations. The government is supposed to protect life, liberty, and happiness. I believe that life takes priority over liberty, and liberty over happiness; therefore, when the life of the child is on the line when a child isn't vaccinated, protection of the life of the child overtakes the liberty of the child's guardians.
You are violating someone's liberty, but when the cost of not doing so is someone's life or future well being?
What's your take on religious exemption from vaccinations?
You aren't free if that is the case. I understand that the road to destruction is paved with good intentions. Just interested what you thought.

Just like there is a political spectrum. There is also a libertarian spectrum, and personally, when people who don't vaccinate effect those who can't vaccinate because of allergies or something else and that person dies, the government should intervene. The people, who don't vaccinate should be getting vaccinated anyway for there own sake. I understand that the path to destruction is made with good intentions, so everyone must be cautious; however, like unguided capitalism ideas may need change. Like child labor laws and if a company becomes a true monopoly it gets broken apart. True Libertarianism has its flaws also (though they are definitely few), and when someone is endangering another person's life, with their liberty I believe that liberty might need to be taken away. Do you have any input?

First of all, chill out. Everyone's immune system is terrible, that's why millions of people died from measles and that's why polio crippled my grandfather. However, your points are valid. But what do you propose to fix the problem? Death by vaccination or by disease? Should the choice be the guardians or the children?

No, the disease killed me through your transmission, and you murdered me with a hammer. My skull didn't kill me. You swinging your hammer onto my head did. This doesn't make any sense. Like not even a bit. This would surely hold up in court. "You see your honor, his skull killed him not me."
I thought you were a libertarian? Words aren't assault unless it is slander or defamation.
I hate to be a grammar nazi, but please spell vaccine properly.
I wish I had that much free time.
What kind of things?
Hopeful, with finals coming to a close that will become a possibility.

When you're in a group when someone makes a joke watch to see who he looks at immediately after. Those people are the people he wants the approval of, and the more people they look at the more insecure they are. This can be used to find weaknesses and attachments in clicks or groups. You can find the weakest person and use their insecurities to get into the group.

I've had sleep paralysis only once in high school. At the time I knew what it was and it scared the crap out of me. It started with a dream. I was lucid dreaming at the time, but I didn't know it. In my dream, I was in my room cleaning on the floor in the arch of my doorway at night. To sister's was sister's room, cracked open just a bit and completely dark. To my right was a hallway pitch black also. When suddenly my sister's door quivered. Now doors don't do that on their own (using my dream logic), so I swung my hand out to hit the door; however, my hand stopped just before I could hit the door, not by my doing. I was suddenly flung into the air. My chest nearing the ceiling my head and back bent backward. I could feel breathing on my neck. Now terrified, I called out for anyone! Everyone! But no cry came out. Not even a hint of breath escaping my mouth. Every name I called me perspective would shift and fly to wherever they were and I would watch each person lift their head from a book and look up as if they thought they heard someone calling their name. Then I would watch as they shrugged off my cry. I called out one more time as I felt teeth brush against my neck. Then I woke up feeling three more breaths on my neck. I had a weight on my chest for thirty more minutes, while sensing a threat still looking in the shadows of my room. Then the weight lifted and I jumped out of bed at the light switch.
No.

Not an obvious one, but the scariest fact I know. The army doesn't hire anyone with an IQ of less than 83. This is scary because the reason for the rule is that it was found that on average people with those scores cannot do anything productive that makes up for their inadequacy. That's about 15% of Americans. That many people cannot be hired because of their smarts by the army, which always needs more manpower. Also, don't say that IQ means nothing. Because it correlates highly with life success, and it is literally a measure of how powerful your brain is. It's not biased, and everyone, who looks into the IQ literature knows that it is sad.
When I was downstairs I was afraid ghosts would come out of the toilet to get me, so I had to get upstairs before the toilet flushed whenever I used it.
Depression.
The first toy story.
Saying hi to your kids.
Russian roulette

I have a few. Probably the scariest moment of my life was opening the first page to my college statistics test in my freshmen year. My second was when my friend's cancer got worse. My third was sleep paralysis. Also, the first day of high school left me shaking.
Guinea pigs.
Capybara
Other people's feelings. I just can't care.

I can't stop laughing when somebody dies in a movie. It's because everyone else is upset and I get really awkward and just start laughing. I also find it extremely hard to care about other people's feelings. It's just so boring.
When somebody handed me a clinical test and I passed a sociopath.
Nope. There's no fixing me.

From a sociopath. No. I don't care about you if don't have anything to offer, and I only empathize with a few specific types of suffering. And sometimes I will pull a few strings to get my way. Does this deserve death?

I was told I was creepy by too many of my friends too many times. I started looking for clinical tests and checked out as a sociopath. The differences between me and them are that I don't use emotion until I have to, I tend to star at peoples eyes and foreheads a little too often when talking to them, I have a really hard time with empathy, I tend to awkwardly laugh at a lot of messed up stuff, and I feel I'm better than others. The last one is the worst thing about myself. It goes in my notebook of daily regrets almost every day.

I'm a middle sociopath. Not a crazy person but not normal in any way. I found out I wasn't normal a long time ago in 6th grade. I don't know what provoked it, but the school decided to run some tests on me. That year I found out I was clinically depressed, I had an anxiety disorder, and I was a genius, by clinical standards (IQ of 145 or above, or around one in ten thousand). I started figuring out that I could learn things super quickly. I would be getting 98s in AP classes. At the same time in high school, I found out I was a sociopath. I took a clinical test and discovered I was a moderate sociopath. Other traits are I have a really hard time with empathy and expressing emotions, which makes me appear creepy. A blank-faced pale skinny high schooler. I don't manipulate I just know I can. Because of my depression I also suffer from regret. I'm regretful of every mistake I've every made and keep them in a list in my head that comes up to haunt me every time I make another mistake. I can make friends easily because of my odd quirky nature, and just because I know exactly how to get people to trust me. I rarely ever dare show my real self. I'm rejected by the smart people of my school of 3000. I just don't fit in anywhere, but no matter. I'll be starting by bachelors in what should be my junior year of high school.
Innocent until proven guilty. Even if chances of guilt are doubled.
I'm not. I just can be.
I found out after my friend got really serious cancer and I don't feel bad. Fine. I just can't empathize, and I know how to make people feel certain feelings.
I can't empathize. My friend got serious leukemia and I don't feel bad. I can use certain tactics to receive the outcome I find desirable. I'm not a prick though.
Order a pizza.
Other people problems. I can't care, but they think I can.

It is kinda funny. My cousin and I are both sociopaths. We make deals to swap all kinds of stuff. Chairs, silver, earbuds. Two people trying to scam each other using different tactics. It's a laugh. We both end up scamming ourselves. Also, we make deals with this one game store owner and use different tactics to get the best deal.
Intelligence and those traits have a moderate correlation. So the world would get dumber.

Coming from a sociopath. Sometimes, when smiling I forget to use the muscles in my eyes to make them a bit squintier, they're really easy to trust, often its a pain to listen to others talk about their problems because of reduced empathy, and often the face will drop to become blank at odd times.
Billy joel

Sometimes. Often we know those cues and make sure to be careful about showing them. I also lie on purpose and make sure it's obvious that I'm lying, so I get a reputation for not lying. Then I can lie to people faces without question.
When my friend got a bad strain of leukemia and I didn't feel a thing. Also when I got a 98 in a college statistics course in my freshman year of high school.
Not caring about my friend contracting leukemia.
Not being a creep. We're normal people, but we know how to get our way and we have problems with empathy.
Once people know you're smart, you become a valuable friend. And they never stop asking for help! Also, it can be lonely because even the smart kids reject you.
I laugh all the time. I just hold deep regret for every mistake I ever made, and my brain registers small failures as huge failures.
The worst of the group define the group, whether political, cultural, or biological.
Birth. Clinical depression isn't made.

Sadness is a state that comes and goes like a passing breeze. Sometimes there are gusts and storms. Depression is a never-ending tornado of deepest regret, self-loathing, and hopelessness, which is only ceased by the sweet release of death. It will not ever vacate but will stay by your side like a parasite, draining you of the will to live; however, it can be ignored, whether by action or drug, but the winds of woe will take you again.

I pulled myself out with discipline. Not with drugs or help or therapy. I hardened myself to my thoughts and feelings, knowing that my depression couldn't be fixed, with it being clinical. I made goals, I planned out my life and broke it into small goals one by one to complete. This day, week, month, year. I bottled up my thoughts about my inadequacy knowing I was on my way to the person I wanted to be. I'm still working on each small task. Every mistake I make with induce a mountain of mental pain, but I bottle it up putting on a smile for the world. I save all the pain and rage for condemning the actions of those, who deserve it. It makes me intense, but I'm functioning.
Anyone, who gets over depression sad not depressed. I define depression as a clinical ailment. An imbalance of chemicals.
I'm clinically depressed.

Intelligence runs in my family. My grandfather went to oxford, two of my cousins are doctors, and one of my cousins is a piano composer, who goes on your in China every summer. I and my sister are both really smart and being really competitive, with GPA becomes a contest. My sister is a junior in college while being a senior in Highschool. We always got along well. She is the book worm and I'm the math nerd. So far I'm at a 4.15 GPA but my sister is close behind.
In 6 the grade. I also tested higher than 145

I take classes that are honors and college classes that shouldn't be taken by people my age and still get 99's. Also, people pester me with questions and make a big scene whenever I make a mistake, I eat jam and olives, but I think that's just me, what would normally take hours for people to memorize takes me minutes, if I open my mouth for too long people figure out I'm smart and never leave me be, so I have to keep my trap closed in classes I'm not supposed to be taking, I'm a humble person, so when people say I'm smart it pisses me off, I have to convince the dumb blond that the lab-made salt water (through the reaction NaO + HCl gt; H2O + NaCl) might not be safe to drink before she dies, and knowing that statistically speaking I will never meet someone like me in my life. P.s. know how to kill a dumb blond? Put scratch and sniff stickers at the bottom of a pool.

When I was in a class full of the smartest kids in a school of 3000 and I surpassed all of them.
Give them an IQ test. And grade it.
No. Have you listened to the long form of her talking? She makes a fool of herself.

Incorrect. There is no way to improve your intelligence/IQ score after a certain age, with the exception of breastfeeding, which will increase hour score by on average around four points. I've looked into the IQ literature and it is depressing. It accurately predicts intelligence. Almost to a tee. In the 60s we ran massive trials and studies trying anything to improve scores. We have found that nothing works. Brain games make you better at brain games. Early education gives you a headstart but the benefits end at around fourth grade. Not increasing scores. Then one question was asked. Perhaps IQ is mostly biological? After that, almost all research was dropped. You can guess why. Reading makes you more knowledgeable but doesn't actually make you smarter. It will also increase reading comprehension. I'm sorry.

WRITING.TITLE: The lord of the rings on LSD.

WRITING.TEXT: I'm a depressed genius sociopath. I went through some mental tests a long time ago. I discovered I was a genius then, and soon after I discovered I was a sociopath after... a mistake. The only interesting experience I can think of was when somebody came up to me once, who I had been talking to for a long time. They told me they felt weird around me all the time like I was radiating bad vibes. They said I made them feel very uncomfortable and worried. It left me shook since then I've managed to catch a few weird looks from people around me. Everyone knows I'm not normal the second I walk into a room. Many people can't put their finger on it. The few I've told what I am to tell me it makes sense. Somehow I know it makes sense too. Maybe I know it makes sense because I catch myself with I blank face when I'm happy, or maybe because I'm a clever loner. I've tried to listen, smile, and laugh but I somehow just put people off. I'll quit monologuing because I know you don't really care about my boring life. But that's my weird experience.
Someone you has a very short fuse, who gets really intense really quickly, and regret.

Why do you perceive the rich as enemies? They are just people trying to make money. Some use bad business practices and they should be called out and pay the price. But as long as all laws are followed why should we care? The truth is that almost all people in the united states are in the global 1%. Are we all bad? No. Rich people should be looked upon not with scorn but will reverence. Our society rewards those, who produce goods, with trading units (money). Great actors, athletes, and inventors are wealthy because they earned it. Some rich people inherited their wealth, but what's wrong there? They didn't deserve it; however, they got the money because someone gave them a gift. And how can we be bad at a gift? If you write a good book you get money because you give a bunch of people entertainment. If you state a company that makes a revolutionary new software that helps the world you get money. And if you invest in a company that does well and helps others, you get money. Some companies like Monsanto sell herbicides to help farmers with weeds and are also rewarded. The only enemies are those, who cheat and use unethical business practices, which are fewer than you think. Scythe. Summary: It's a book series that currently has only two books and the third and likely final will come out in 2020. It begins in a future where all disease and aging has been stopped. The only way to die is by fire and acid, which cannot be healed, or by a scythe. The world is run by a super intelligent AI called the thunderhead, but at the same time a separate government, the order of the scythe, is in charge of... Overpopulation. They must kill. Scythes are meant to kill, but like regular people, they grieve for there actions. But some enjoy the killing and they are trying to overthrow the old guard of the scythe.

I get up and get back to work.

An ultra-massive black hole. Because they have an estimated life span of 10^120 years to Hawking radiation.

Black holes the remains of really big stars. Stars run on nuclear fusion, which is the reaction that makes hydrogen bombs possible. When all that mass is collected into one spot, it begins to squeeze itself into a very small spot, and when you squeeze atoms together hard enough, for example, hydrogen, they become one atom helium; however, the mass of the helium atom will be less than the mass of the two hydrogen atoms, which means that some of the mass turned into energy via E=mc^2. This release of energy keeps the mass of the star from squishing itself into a smaller space. It's a balance between the fusion reaction and the mass of the star, but soon the hydrogen will run out if the star is really big. The helium fuses into carbon; the carbon to neon; the neon to iron; and iron to lead. Lead cannot be fused any further, so the reaction dies and along with it, the star collapses. The gravitational force keeps pulling down until the protons and electrons fuse together and become neutrons, which makes them star into a neutron star. If the mass is still crushing down the hadrons themselves get ripped apart into strange matter. A quark-gluon soup. If the mass is great enough even the elementary particles break and the star becomes a black hole. Theoretically, the mass keeps getting crushed into a zero-dimensional point, a singularity. The gravity around this is so strong that photons, the waves/particles that interact with the electromagnetic field, or light, cannot escape its gravity. The star is now a black hole. There are supermassive black holes, which reside at the center of galaxies, and some of these at so huge we call them ultra-massive black holes, these are black holes with billions of times the mass of our sun. There has been some speculation about black holes that they violate the first law of thermodynamics (no mass can be destroyed or created); however, I recently went to a lecture that disproved this hypothesis. Without explaining the mathematical proof of this, which made that lecture quite dull, because of quantum flux (small particles and antiparticles that pop in and out of existence, which then annihilate each other because the universe finest care about the first law of thermodynamics as long as the average of the mass in the universe is still the same), the black hole will slowly lose its mass by Hawking radiation ( the process by which a particle and an antiparticle pop in and out of existence near the event horizon of the black hole, where one tiny particle falls in and one escapes from the black hole, and because the universe says that this can't happen it removes a particle from the black hole so that the particle, which escaped can safely exist.

Being smart is being good at solving problems, a good memory, good at absorbing commend knowledge, vocabulary, and reading ability (all things tested on official IQ tests. Wisdom is life experience; it's staying calm while being yelled at by the foolish; it's staying silent while the foolish yell curses; it's knowing to live for the future and not the present or past; its not standing for truth its the willingness to sit in jail for truth; its selflessness not selfishness; its overlooking an insult to your own glory. Wisdom stands and shouts in the streets and announces herself to all, who are simple. You will know wisdom when she appears.

First of all, this sounds like a question that should end with a 'hypothetically speaking.' You should get them into a situation where conversation is almost forced. Like a restaurant. Next, you either pick blunt or roundabout. If blunt then just tell them what's on your mind. If roundabout then start with something that has nothing to do with the issue. Then slowly push the conversation where you need it to go to. If they try to redirect, pull them right back. Do not get mad. Stay calm. If they get angry, calm them down. Be perfectly logical. Write out the problem and the conversation. Plan it out. Remove your own paradoxes. I'm assuming a lot, but I hope this helps. Also, remember that an underserved curse never comes to rest. So don't make it worse.

Thanks for the information. You avoided information about the falling out and it would be helpful if you told me that also; however, if you would rather not divulge I will still try to assess the situation and help. This is only speculation, but from what you've told me, this person at first appeared to want to mend things but has since broken off the remaining ties between you two. Also, from what you have said about this person, she appears to have several toxic traits. This leads me to believe that she wanted to cause you some emotional turmoil as one last middle finger. It my understanding that she first wanted to open you up with a kind photo and some appearances of trying to mend things only to then block you and leave you with some very mixed feelings. This is likely chalking up ignorance and mistakes to malice. Nevertheless, this is one conclusion that can be made from the information. She may have blocked the wrong person. Check. She may have blocked you a while ago when she was mad at you (assumptions). Check. Talk to her. Don't avoid conversation. If you don't ask, you won't know. If she doesn't answer or you can't contact her... Then if you ever stumble across her again be kind and forgive. If you can contact her make sure you aren't pointing the blame anywhere for obvious reasons. Plan fun things to do together. Spend more time together. These take a long time to write and I need to go. I hope this helps.

As a sociopath, I think you need to know what you're talking about. Narcissism isn't selfishness. True narcissism is where you can't think about others. A bird will hit your window and you will think that the bird is trying to tell you something. It has to be about you. It can't just be a bird has hit a window. It's more than just selfishness. Sociopathy can be seen as a bell curve where the average is very little trait Sociopathy. The sociopathic traits are selfishness, a lack of empathy, which leads to manipulativeness. Psychopathy can also be seen as a bell curve but the been is much less than the latter. This is essentially sociopathy, but with more violent tendencies. Narcissism is a mental illness; however, I believe that sociopaths and psychopaths are just people who have abnormal personality traits, which help them succeed! Most executives are sociopaths!

Needless to say, he didn't approve and gave me a tardy, after of course, his eyebrows finished twitching.
This sounds like you were suffering from loneliness, not depression. That may have made you depressed, but you didn't have depression.

Depression isn't something that can be talked about in the past tense in the mental illness sense. Depression cannot be cured by anything. It can be treated through therapy and medication, but not cured.

You had toxic friends, which made your view of yourself shine in poorer light, and it can be hard to find good friends. This made you feel depressed. I'm not saying that your feelings are irrelevant, nor that your efforts we're vain; however, I believe that you didn't have depression in the mental illness sense because that never goes away. It stays with you forever. It can be treated, yes, but it cannot be cured.

Being calm. A person easily angered displays to everyone their foolishness. Not provoking people for no reason, because like a fluttering sparrow an undeserved curse never comes to rest. Setting aside the present for the future. A little sleep, a little slumber, a little resting of the hands, and like a thief in the night poverty will flood your lands. Taking responsibility. Everyone believes in pollution. Does anyone see trash on the ground and say, "look! A figment of my imagination." I believe in both, but I'm not too concerned about global warming. We can just switch to nuclear energy, which has zero emissions. Why all the expensive solar and wind? We can engineer sea walls, Big dikes. Anyway, the climate does change from time to time, and we will adapt. An example of nuclear power would be France. Most of their power comes from nuclear. They almost no power issues. Germany has switched to almost all solar and wind and they have power problems all the time. People have this dream of a future of only solar and wind, but it's just not going to happen anytime soon.

Thanks for the clarification. I would say it's not a smart idea to deregulate it. Coal and oil are the real killers. If you look at what kinds of power put out the most carbon it would be coal, oil, then natural gas, then a few others, and it's significantly better then the first two. Some natural gas plants actually calculate how much carbon they output then they collect that much carbon out of the air and use it to power the plant! If our goal is to reduce carbon emissions while causing as little harm to the economy and to our pockets (taxes). We would want to first start removing coal and oil then make sure that all other fissile fuel power stations emit a minimal amount of carbon then we can construct more nuclear power plants, and also build some wind and solar plants also.
